description: From Middle English losengeour, losenger, from Old French losengier, losengeor, from losengier (“to deceive, flatter”), losenge (“flattery”), flattery, Occitan lauzenga, from Latin laus praise. Compare lozenge.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A flatterer; a deceiver; a cozener.
examples: To a fair pair of gallows, there to end their lives with shame, as a number of such other losengers had done.
